clinicalDescription: Overview: Most common sexually transmitted infection (STI), viral infection. HPV infection occurs when the virus enters the body, usually through a cut, abrasion or small tear in your skin. The virus is transferred primarily by skin-to-skin contact. There are more than 100 varieties of HPV. Some types of HPV infection cause warts, and some can cause different types of cancer.Presentation: Warts do not always appear and can have no symptoms. Warts appear depending on which kind of HPV is involved - genital warts, hands/fingers, plantar, or face Assessment: Appearance of warts, but if not present - Vinegar (acetic acid) solution test, pap test, DNA test Plan: Medication applied directly to the warts. Cryotherapy, electrocautery, surgical removal/laser surgery. HPV vaccines (protect against cervical cancer and genital warts). If HPV in the cervix - colposcopy and biopsy. Prognosis: Nearly all cervical cancers are caused by HPV infections. Warts often go away without treatment, particularly in children. There's no cure for the virus, so they can reappear in the same place or other places.
